question: Question_05_(c)
sols:
Here we have several compositions going on. So a first step, would be to
compute the derivative of

\[\displaystyle
\ln(x^2+2x)\]

We do this using the chain rule:

\[\displaystyle
( p(q(x)) )' = p'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)\]

Here we have that

\[\displaystyle
p(x) = \ln(x) \qquad q(x) = x^2+2x\] and

\[\displaystyle
p'(x) = \frac{1}{x} \qquad q'(x) = 2x+2\]

And so:

\[\displaystyle
( \ln(x^2+2x) )' = \frac{1}{x^2+2x} (2x+2) = \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}\]

And so now, we can use the chain rule again to compute the derivative of

\[\displaystyle
\ln(\ln(x^2+2x))\]

Using:

\[\displaystyle
( p(q(x)) )' = p'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)\]

Where

\[\displaystyle
p(x) = \ln(x) \qquad q(x) = \ln(x^2+2x)\] and we have

\[\displaystyle
p'(x) = \frac{1}{x} \qquad q'(x) = \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}\]

And so we obtain

\[\displaystyle
h'(x) = \frac{1}{\ln(x^2+2x)} \cdot \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}\]
hints: Watch out for the multiple use of the chain rule.
